Quatrièmement, une enveloppe de 100 M€ sera déléguée aux Agences régionales de santé pour organiser la gestion des ressources humaines : gestion des plates-forme ; financement des gardes d’enfant et logement ; financement des renforts. Mesdames et Messieurs, Mes chers concitoyens, L’ensemble des mesures que nous annonçons aujourd’hui seront précisées et adaptées d’ici samedi. Nous le ferons dans un cadre concerté : avec les partenaires sociaux, avec les représentants des secteurs professionnels, avec les élus locaux avec qui je suis en lien constant et que je veux encore remercier, avec les partis politiques et les groupes parlementaires que je recevrai une nouvelle fois la semaine prochaine, pour notamment évoquer avec eux l’impact de la dégradation de la situation sanitaire sur l’organisation des prochaines échéances électorales. Beaucoup de questions se règlent par l’écoute et le dialogue. Nous traversons un moment inédit de notre histoire. Un moment appelé à durer encore plusieurs mois. Et comme toujours dans les moments difficiles, la tentation est grande de rechercher les boucs émissaires, d’opposer les uns aux autres, de nous perdre dans de vaines polémiques. Le moment viendra, lorsque cette crise sanitaire sera terminée –et elle se terminera !-, d’en tirer sereinement toutes les conséquences et tous les enseignements. Mais pour l’heure, toutes nos énergies doivent être tournées vers ce combat contre la maladie et sa propagation. C’est à notre portée, si nous sommes solidaires, si nous sommes responsables. L’Etat et le Gouvernement dans son ensemble sont bien entendu en 1ère ligne, pour vous protéger et prendre les mesures que la situation exige, comme le font du reste l’ensemble des autorités politiques des pays voisins. Mais ce n’est pas l’Etat qui frappe, c’est le virus ! C’est lui notre objectif commun, c’est face à lui que nous devons unir nos forces et nos volontés. La France est un grand pays : ensemble, nous surmonterons cette épreuve, j’en ai la conviction. Nous nous tenons à votre disposition pour répondre à vos questions.
topics_EN: Press conference on the application of measures against COVID-19
speeches_EN: Ladies and Gentlemen, We are meeting again this afternoon to present to you the details of the new provisions that the President of the Republic announced last night concerning the management of the epidemic crisis. As you know, we took the decision yesterday in the Council of Ministers to place our country in a state of health emergency from next Saturday at midnight, or if you prefer, from Friday at midnight. This decision is valid for a minimum period of 4 weeks and is intended to be extended beyond that, if Parliament validates it, on the basis of a bill which will be submitted to it next week. Evolution of the epidemiological situation This decision draws the consequences of the deterioration of the viral circulation that we have been observing for ten days. Because in France, as in all the countries around us, the epidemic is experiencing a clear rebound which allows us to consider that the second wave of the epidemic has arrived. If we look at the evolution of the epidemic since deconfinement last May, we can observe: A phase of marked reduction in traffic from mid-May to mid-July, with a number of cases which was then to 7 people per 100,000; A slow but real increase in traffic during the summer and until mid-September which led me to take, during the summer, a first series of measures focused on wearing a mask compulsory, in public spaces, at work, in shops, cinemas and performance halls. At the beginning of August, I also wrote to all the metropolises and large towns to ask them to draw up an action plan to protect the most vulnerable people. Then, a slowdown phase from the second half of September when the various measures taken in the main affected cities have made it possible to mark a stabilization, even a decline, in particular in Bordeaux, Nice, Rennes and in other cities; And finally, for ten days, a sudden acceleration and spectacular: between October 1 and 12, the number of cases per 100,000 people in the whole of France rose from 107 to 190, with particularly alarming levels in certain large cities: 500 in Lille and Saint-Etienne, 422 in Grenoble, nearly 400 in Lyon and Paris. Consequence: resuscitation capacities are already very much in demand, in particular in Paris where 46% of resuscitation beds are occupied by Covid patients. The most worrying thing is that the number of new cases is increasing very rapidly among the elderly, which we know will result in the arrival of many new patients in the hospital very soon. This evolution can be observed, as I said, with us as everywhere with our neighbours. It requires a strong and rapid reaction because it is not possible to let our hospitals deal with the risk of a number of serious illnesses which would quickly and massively exceed our capacities, even though it is no longer possible, as in during the first wave, to massively deprogram other serious pathologies. Our healthcare professionals, admirable and heroic during the first wave, are tired and tried. I want to pay them a strong tribute and tell them, Olivier Véran will come back to this, that we are doing everything we can to support them in the face of this new wave of the epidemic. But I would like to clarify one point from the outset: I hear that the right answer would have been to massively create additional intensive care beds rather than take measures to curb the epidemic. This is doubly wrong: no hospital system would be able to cope with the consequences of such an epidemic which could lead to tens of thousands of serious hospitalizations if we did nothing to stop it; and especially to create beds, it is not enough to equip oneself with equipment and premises, it is also necessary to train doctors and specialized nursing staff. It is impossible in a few months, it requires several years. To relieve our caregivers and reduce the number of patients, the only real possible strategy is therefore to curb the epidemic by strictly respecting barrier measures and reducing contacts and social interactions. We have adopted a graduated and territorialized response strategy, preferring targeted measures, city by city, territory by territory, rather than generalized bans. We are betting on trust with local elected officials, first and foremost the mayors, with whom we are in constant dialogue. I want to say it again, without them, without the help of their services, and those of other communities, with the backing of specialized associations, which come to the aid of the most precarious, who take care of the most vulnerable, we will not succeed. . All these measures have borne fruit. At work, at school, in transport, we have reached the right point of balance. I note in particular that the start of the school year went well. Today, only 29 establishments out of 62,000 and 274 classes out of 530,000 are closed throughout the national territory. I thank all the actors of the educational community. A very high risk area appears to be the most difficult to control: places where gatherings or parties take place, with family or friends. Where there are many of us, where we are close together, for a certain period of time, where we do not wear a mask and where we lose the reflex of barrier measures. This is where we are at risk. This is where we must act as a priority and collectively. This is why we have tightened the measures on bars and restaurants. First in Marseille and Bordeaux in mid-September. Then, in recent weeks, in 14 major cities in France and in Guadeloupe. The sharp and rapid deterioration in the health situation shows that this is not enough, despite the efforts of all professionals, especially restaurateurs. It is with the aim of limiting these risky interactions that we have decided to impose a health curfew in nine metropolises, which will apply to public spaces but which will also aim to reduce interactions in the private sphere during next weeks. This starts with a general watchword: reduce the number of people we meet in a friendly setting, at home, in restaurants, in moments of conviviality outside. This is the 6-person rule that we have applied to restaurants, that we will apply to gatherings in public space, and that we ask everyone to respect at home. This then goes through a new device, this health curfew measure which will therefore come into force tomorrow Friday at midnight. I will now tell you how. The territories subject to this curfew are: Paris and the 7 other departments of Ile de France; The metropolises of Lyon, Lille, Toulouse, Montpellier, Saint-Etienne, Aix-Marseille, Rouen and Grenoble. The curfew will be from 9 p.m. to 6 a.m. This means that at 9 p.m., everyone must be at home, and that, with some exceptions, all places, businesses or services open to the public will be closed. These rules must of course be applied with common sense. As during confinement, certain trips will remain authorized: For health reasons, to go to the hospital or to buy medicine in a duty pharmacy, for example; For professional reasons, if you work at night or your working hours work do not allow you to be home at 9 p.m.; If you have a train or plane that arrives or leaves after 9 p.m.; if necessary, you will need to be able to show your ticket if you are checked; If you have to go to see a dependent relative; - To take your pet out, near you. As during the confinement period, you will need to come out after 9 p.m. with a certificate proving that you meet one of these exceptions. The certificate and all the information concerning the health situation and the measures relating to the curfew are available on the government website or by calling the toll-free number 0 800 130 000. Similarly, some establishments will naturally escape closure. anticipated: these are health and medico-social establishments, the most precarious reception structures, hotels, restaurants providing home delivery, and public establishments that provide evening and nighttime service such as the police stations. In these curfew areas, stricter rules will continue to apply during the day. For example, drinking establishments will remain closed; sports halls also closed, except for children and professional athletes who apply specific protocols. Universities and higher education establishments will apply occupancy rules limiting the on-site presence of students and the occupation of teaching places to 50%. I count on the sense of responsibility of each and every one of you to apply these rules. I asked that our control system be adapted to these new rules and this system will be presented to you by the Minister of the Interior. [Intervention by Mr Gérald DARMANIN] Good morning to you, Prime Minister, indeed, the Ministry of the Interior will be responsible for the application, as during confinement, of measures which will be harsher, if I may say so, during this curfew, from 9 p.m. to 6 a.m., in the areas mentioned by the Prime Minister. I repeat: the whole of the Île-de-France region, that is to say Paris, of course, and 3 departments in the inner suburbs: Seine-Saint-Denis, Hauts-de-Seine, Val -de-Marne, as well as the outermost departments: Essonne, Val-d'Oise, Yvelines and Seine-et-Marne, and the 8 metropolises mentioned by the Prime Minister: Lille, Lyon, AixMarseille, Grenoble, Toulouse, Montpellier, Saint-Etienne and Rouen. To do this, 12,000 police officers and gendarmes are specially tasked each night, between 9 p.m. and who will also be able with the municipal police, when the mayors organize the night services or already organize them, to enforce the rules mentioned by the Prime Minister, which come into force on the night of Friday to Saturday from midnight. I would also like to mention that on the website of the Ministry of the Interior, there will be the possibility of being able to download the new certificate with the measures mentioned by the Prime Minister, the possibility of downloading it to his telephone and being able to keep it on his smartphone for those who obviously have it, which will be recharged every hour, since the certificate is worth one hour when it comes to trips that have no connection with work. And of course, we can always continue to write on free paper, especially for the oldest people or people who do not have a printer or photocopier immediately available, this derogatory travel certificate. For the professional certificate which shows that we will indeed be able to return home, go to work or work, not only will the certificate, digital or paper, be required, but in addition the proof of his company or his professional card when you are a liberal nurse or a journalist, for example. That's what I wanted to say in a nutshell. Obviously, there are sanctions that are applied when people do not respect the prohibitions of this curfew from 9:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m., which only applies in the areas mentioned by the Prime Minister: a fine of 135 euros, i.e. the same fine as during confinement. And if ever there should be a repetition, that is to say, if after 3 times, the police or the gendarmes manage to confuse a person who, by 3 times, cheats or does not respect these rules of prohibition , 6 months possible imprisonment and a fine of 3,750 euros. Furthermore, of course, I asked the police, the gendarmes, under the authority of the Prime Minister, to enforce the rules concerning establishments, in particular establishments which receive the public, indeed, to be able to intervene in a way vigorous when, in particular in the areas most at risk, but also in all the other areas, in France, we have this subject of untimely regrouping in places which do not respect the health rules and which receive the public and the rule of 6 , obviously, an incentive rule for which the police and the gendarmes will continue to do pedagogy, obviously closer to the population. [End of intervention by Mr Gérald DARMANIN] Thank you, Minister of the Interior. Controls will be tightened. So much for the territories where the curfew will be applicable. In territories other than those where the curfew will apply, the prefects will continue to adapt the rules according to epidemic realities, but general measures will also apply to the entire territory, since the entire national territory will be placed in a state of emergency. health emergency from Saturday. These rules, which will apply everywhere, are as follows: All private parties, such as weddings or student parties, held in party rooms, multipurpose rooms or any other establishment open to the public will be prohibited; All restaurants de France will apply the health protocol which has recently been reinforced and provides in particular for the limitation of the number of customers per table to 6 and the recording of customer names to facilitate contact tracing; In all places where you are seated – such as cinemas , stadiums, circuses or conference rooms – the rule of one seat out of two must apply (between two people, or between two families or groups of friends of 6 people maximum), and, by prefectural decree, the number of visitors will be limited to 1,000 or 5,000 people depending on the level of circulation of the virus; In all places where people walk standing – such as shopping centers and supermarkets, museums, fairs and shows, zoos – the number of visitors will be limited on the basis of a rule of 4 m2 per person and within the limit of a gauge set by the prefect, again depending on the level of circulation of the virus. There will therefore be two regimes corresponding to two territorial situations: general rules applying everywhere in the country and reinforced rules for metropolitan areas subject to curfew. These rules will apply for a period of 4 weeks, and we will ask Parliament to extend them until the end of November, the time to slow down the epidemic and unclog our health system. We will also invite companies and public administrations to develop the use of telework, under the conditions that the Minister of Labor will present to you. [Intervention by Mrs Elisabeth BORNE] Thank you Mr Prime Minister. So, you know, that in business a very strict national protocol applies which provides in particular since September 1st, the obligation to wear a mask in all closed and shared work spaces. This protocol is effective, there is no chain of contamination when this protocol is applied and this protocol is very well applied. There have been more than 50,000 labor inspection checks since confinement and there have only been 300 formal notices. This shows that thanks to this very strict protocol, employees can go to work in complete safety. As the protocol states, the use of telework is a relevant method of organization to reduce the spread of the virus. It makes it possible to limit contact at work, but also around the workplace and on home-work journeys. Its implementation must respect a balance between several objectives. First of all, to prevent the spread of the virus, but also to maintain the efficiency of work organizations and finally, to prevent the risks linked to the isolation of employees. This balance must be built through social dialogue within the company. This morning, with Laurent PIETRASZEWSKI, we brought together the social partners to take stock of the implementation of the national protocol in companies and discuss the adaptations to be made. I would like to emphasize that the exchanges showed a very strong, a very strong responsibility on the part of all the social partners, but also the shared observation on the effectiveness of the protocol. We have decided to make two main changes to the national protocol. Companies, and especially those in areas where the curfew applies, are now asked to define a minimum number of telework days per week for positions that allow it and also to spread out the hours. arriving and leaving work. The methods of implementation, for example the number of days of telework, must be the subject of social dialogue within the company. We want to make these changes, so this new protocol applicable from next week, on which we have asked the social partners to send us their comments during the day for the new protocol to be posted online tomorrow. [End of intervention by Mrs. Elisabeth BORNE] Thank you. With regard to the civil service, throughout the territory and whenever this can be reconciled with the needs of the service, the administrations will define as of next week a work organization integrating the needs of the service and allowing, each time that this will be possible, two to three days of teleworking per week. These provisions will have an economic impact on economic sectors and professional sectors. We will therefore be called upon to strengthen and extend our support and support systems, in line with the responses that we have been able to provide since the start of the crisis in the face of the economic and social emergency. An economic emergency plan has been implemented in order to protect employees through the partial unemployment scheme, the most generous in Europe, to support companies' cash flow (through the solidarity fund, the loan scheme guaranteed by the State and deferrals and exemptions from social contributions) and to limit the persistence of the effects of the crisis on the productive apparatus and skills. Over the past few weeks, we have taken additional measures to strengthen our support for companies directly or indirectly impacted by our braking measures taken in major cities. And at the request of the President of the Republic, we will further adapt and strengthen these systems in the context of the state of health emergency that we have just decreed. These measures will be prepared and agreed with professionals by the end of next week by the ministers concerned, first and foremost Bruno Le Maire to whom I give the floor. [Intervention by Mr Bruno LE MAIRE] Thank you Prime Minister. Ladies and gentlemen, as the Prime Minister has just indicated, since the beginning of this crisis we have been alongside entrepreneurs and employees affected by the economic crisis and by health safety rules. And we will continue to be after the announcement of this curfew. I had the opportunity this morning to discuss with all the managers of the hotel, catering, café, culture and event sectors, and I want to tell them that I fully appreciate their dismay. . They had started to recover, they had started to reopen and its health obligations are like a cold shower to them. We will be at their side and we will continue to be at their side by strengthening, at the request of the President of the Republic and the Prime Minister, the measures that are already in force. Everything that needs to be done will be done to allow them to get through these weeks of curfew with as little economic impact as possible. We will first strengthen once again, simplify and expand the Solidarity Fund. All companies with less than 50 employees which are located in curfew areas and which have lost 50% of their turnover compared to 2019 will be able to benefit from aid of up to 1500 euros, and this during the entire duration of the curfew. This means very concretely that we are restoring the Solidarity Fund for all companies with fewer than 50 employees, regardless of the sector to which they belong. This is the safety net we are putting in place for all businesses within the perimeter of the curfew. Second element on the Solidarity Fund, for companies with less than 50 employees in the hotel, café and catering, culture, events, sports sectors, the famous S1 and S1 bis sectors such as that they have been extended by the Prime Minister, we are opening up to them aid from the Solidarity Fund, which goes up to 10,000 euros per month for these sectors when they suffer a loss of turnover of no more than 70% but 50%. It is therefore a significant enlargement for companies, which would no longer lose 70 but 50% of their turnover. Third element on the Solidarity Fund, as the President of the Republic had indicated last night, we are going to improve the mechanism of the ceiling. You know that until now all of these solidarity fund schemes are capped at 60% of turnover for all the companies concerned. As of Saturday, we are removing the 60% cap on the turnover of this aid for the hotel, café and restaurant sectors, the S1 and S1 bis sectors. These three changes to the Solidarity Fund wanted by the Prime Minister and the President of the Republic constitute very significant assistance for all the sectors affected by the new health restrictions. The second element is the exemptions from charges which, as you know, have been one of the very powerful mechanisms for supporting the economic sector. All companies that are administratively closed will benefit from a total exemption from their social and employer contributions until the end of the curfew. Companies in the hotel, café and catering sector which are located in the curfew zones which the Prime Minister has just announced, will also be able to benefit from a total exemption from employer social security contributions as soon as they lose 50% of their turnover. . There are still employee social security contributions, since I was talking about employers' social security contributions. We will provide aid for these wage social security contributions of up to 20% of the payroll, which in reality makes it possible to fully cover the weight of social charges for the entrepreneurs concerned. The measures we are taking with the Prime Minister make it possible to fully cover the weight of social charges for the entrepreneurs concerned. All of these measures will be included in the 2021 Social Security financing bill and all of these measures, exemptions from charges and strengthening of the solidarity fund, represent a cost to public finances of one billion euros over the duration of the curfew. Third element, state-guaranteed loans which, as you know, are also one of the elements which, since the beginning of March, have provided massive support to the economy. 120 billion euros in loans guaranteed by the State have already been issued. There are also state-guaranteed seasonal loans, which are very important for the hotel and restaurant sector since their ceiling is no longer set at 25% of turnover but at the best three months of the year 2019, which is much more advantageous for these hotel and catering companies because it can represent up to 80 or 90% of their turnover, since three months can simply represent the summer season . These state-guaranteed loans, which were available until December 31 of this year 2020, will now be accessible until June 30, 2021. It is therefore a six-month extension of these state-guaranteed loans, there also, as the President of the Republic indicated last night. Second very significant element on these loans guaranteed by the State, you know that many companies wish to be able to postpone the repayment of these loans because they say to themselves: “we are coming to the end of these loans, we will have to repay them, we can not". We are asking the French Banking Federation to consider deferring the repayment of these loans for an additional year for companies that really need them. Flexibility should be the rule here. I had the opportunity to discuss this morning with Philippe BRASSAC, the President of the French Banking Federation and Managing Director of Crédit Agricole, and I thank him for his understanding on the subject. Fourth element of support for all economic sectors affected by the economic crisis are direct loans from the State. We have set up, at the request of the Prime Minister, direct loans from the State for the companies most in difficulty. They are extended until June 30, 2021. These are really loans that are for all the companies that have knocked on all the doors, who have not been able to find an answer to their situation and who need the help direct from the state. It is a direct loan from the State. We are going to set up a single national telephone number in Bercy which will be available within a fortnight and which will allow a company, an SME, a VSE which has found absolutely no solution to call the Ministry of the Economy directly. and Finance and find out about these direct government loans. As the Prime Minister indicated, all these immediate, powerful measures do not exhaust the questions of the sectors which are concerned and we must therefore continue the consultation, continue the consultation with them. At the request of the Prime Minister, I will therefore receive, with Elisabeth BORNE and Alain GRISET, the heads of the hotel, coffee, catering, event sector and sport sectors to examine with them all the solutions that must be made to specific, urgent and important requests which are now on the table. I cite three. The first is rents. It's an incredibly complicated subject. There are large donors, there are small private donors. There is no miracle solution on rents, but we have a requirement for results on this issue which, I know, worries many entrepreneurs. We are ready to discuss all possible solutions, including a tax credit for lessors. On paid holidays, we know, with Elisabeth BORNE, that it is a time bomb for many restaurateurs. We will deal with this subject with Elisabeth BORNE as soon as possible. The third subject is insurance. Many restaurateurs and hoteliers are worried about the letters they receive, which tell them that they can no longer be covered by the risks of a pandemic. This causes a lot of concern, especially in the hotel and restaurant sector. We will therefore finalize, in the coming weeks, a new insurance plan for companies in the event of a health disaster involving an administrative closure. On the cultural sector, which must also be very directly affected: theatres, cinemas, performance halls, with the obligation of a curfew at 9 p.m., the Prime Minister asked me to initiate discussions tomorrow morning with Roselyne BACHELOT, the Minister of Culture, to meet their expectations and find the most appropriate solutions possible. Finally, with regard to associations, I know their concerns which were reported to me by Olivia GRÉGOIRE, they are subject to additional costs which are associated with the health crisis. Here too, we will answer it, with Olivia GRÉGOIRE, in the coming days. [End of intervention by Mr Bruno LE MAIRE] Thank you very much, Minister. Beyond the solidarity that we owe to the sectors most impacted by the curfew and health measures, we are primarily attentive to those who are the first victims of the crisis. I think first of all of the youngest. In July, I presented a "One young person, one solution" plan - with exceptional resources. We provide strong support for hiring, whether under an employment contract or a contract and apprenticeship with bonuses to companies to speed up their recruitment of young people. We are massively reinforcing qualifying training oriented towards ecological transition and jobs of the future: 200,000 more training places. As of this start of the school year, we have created 26,500 new places in inclusive training. Finally, because some young people have dropped out and need help to reintegrate them, we have created all the gateways to activity: 300,000 integration courses and contracts will be gradually rolled out. There are already some encouraging signs. If we take the example of apprenticeship, the first indications of the start of the 2020 school year are good despite the crisis: for a large majority of professions, entries into apprenticeships are stable or even up slightly compared to the year. last one which was exceptional. It increases in construction, in health, in crafts and in other sectors. We are mobilized to accelerate the deployment throughout the territories of the plan for young people, which is one of the government's priorities. I am also thinking of the most fragile, poorest and most vulnerable groups. As the President of the Republic announced yesterday, a bonus of €150 will be paid to each person benefiting from RSA, ASS and APL. To these 150 euros will be added an additional 100 € per child. This aid will be paid before the end of the year. It will affect 4.1 million households. I will have the opportunity to specify and complete these measures on Saturday on the occasion of the World Day for the Eradication of Extreme Poverty. To conclude, I would like to return to the crucial question of adapting our healthcare system to the very strong episode it is already facing and which will worsen in the coming days and weeks. Olivier VÉRAN, to whom I would like to pay special tribute, for his courage and determination in the face of this crisis, will give you an update on this subject. Minister. [Intervention by Mr Olivier VÉRAN] Thank you very much, Prime Minister. A few progress points in addition to the points that were previously discussed at previous press conferences. First on the question of tests and to come back to what the President of the Republic said last night. First, we are winning the battle over test access delays. As you know, we met, our country as in other countries, despite the fact that it tested a lot thanks to the tremendous mobilization of the entire biology sector, in town as in the hospital, we encountered delays which had become increasing on the occasion of the start of the new school year, returns from holidays, returns to companies, returns to school. This battle of deadlines, we are in the process of winning it, as I said, with figures which attest to it since now, 91% of PCR tests are returned in less than 48 hours. A median delay which has increased to just over 24 hours for the return of these tests and barnums, these delocalized test centers which have been set up by regional health agencies and intended for priority audiences. These barnums are not filling up, a sign that the situation is much less tense. To tell the truth, we have come back to examination rendering indicators which are close to those we encountered during the month of July, or even at the beginning of August, when the tensions were not palpable on the ground. And yet, the number of tests has increased again since it again exceeds 1,300,000 per week. But the challenge in terms of tests and the President of the Republic spoke about it yesterday, are these famous antigenic tests. I remind you, nasal-pharyngeal swabs with a swab in the nose. The same as those of you who have had a PCR exam know. And then, instead of sending it to a laboratory, we can do the manipulations directly on site which allow you to have the result between 10 and 30 minutes, depending on the tests. We had, without waiting for the scientific recommendations ordered, 5 million antigenic tests which have already been deployed for several days in all French regions. And quietly, experiments are conducted on specific audiences, such as medical students, nursing students, but also hospital admissions in the emergency rooms of certain hospitals. 5 million tests is a lot, but it's not enough. And so, we now have all the recommendations of the High Authority for Health to soon allow hospitals, but also private doctors, community pharmacists, private nurses to be able to acquire these tests as well as the appropriate protective equipment and to be able to take these samples directly. It's going to take some time, time needed for training, time needed for organization, time needed for the tests to arrive. But already, we are fully mobilized on this path. It will not replace the PCR tests and we will always need the biology sector. But we can imagine. We can even hope. We can even expect that within a few weeks, a person who has a fever with respiratory signs can be tested directly by his doctor if he participates in this movement of antigenic tests. In addition, barnums, these famous collective testing operations, could be carried out from these antigenic tests in airports, for example, allowing, when people arrive on national territory from a country where the virus circulates a lot , to have their results before leaving the airport. Which is, you'll admit, still better. This is an innovation that is winning over France like the rest of Europe, and we are extremely mobilized. Second quick point on what is called contact tracing, it is to alert when we contact people who are positive to go around all the people they could have infected without knowing it, the famous contacts. First, what we see both at the level of health insurance and regional health agencies, as well as city doctors who are mobilized on this contact tracing action, is that most of the time, now, the contact cases were informed by the patients themselves, which is obviously good but which does not prevent doubling this with a call to verify that the sheltering, which was called before the isolation takes place in the best conditions and that people lack nothing. More than 90% of patients are contacted within the first 24 hours. A sign that the system, which is under great strain by the large number of patients, more than 20,000 per day, this system is still working. And the President of the Republic spoke yesterday about the change in the application which will be called "all anti-Covid", which was not a change of name, which is a change of philosophy, which is a change of dimensioning and which will be a fully effective application to meet the challenges posed by the epidemic. Cédric O is working hard as Secretary of State in charge of digital and we will have the chance to make a presentation of this new application in a few days to whom we will obviously wish us long life. A point on the situation in hospitals Mr. Prime Minister, this is an important point and we are indeed seeing a certain number of questions emerge. You talked about it. Why haven't you increased intensive care beds in the country? We wouldn't have to have a curfew if we had 20,000 or 30,000 sheaves. First of all, and everyone can understand, a resuscitator anesthetist is 11 years of training. We removed the numerus clausus two years ago. But before, well, there were limitations on the number of doctors in training, which is unfortunate, but we made that decision two years ago. We cannot therefore identify resuscitator anesthesiologists like that. In the same way for nurses, nursing assistants who work in the sheave department, these are very special care to be done with intubated patients, ventilated, with respiratory assistance. Nevertheless, practical training has obviously been put in place since the first epidemic wave. In Parisian hospitals alone, 750 nurses and nursing assistants participated in training allowing them tomorrow, if the situation were to require it, to strengthen the workforce in the intensive care unit. But our goal is not to fill up the sheaves and our goal is not to have an infinitely expandable number of sheaves. It should be understood that during the first wave for 17,000 patients admitted for readmission, there were 30,000 deaths. What we want is to prevent serious cases. And for 1 serious case in intensive care that we talk about in the statistics there are a certain number of less serious cases, sometimes those but still loss of taste, smell, a significant and severe cough, resistant fatigue. These symptoms can affect people who are younger than those usually found in intensive care units. This is why we really need to, our philosophy is to prevent serious cases and it is therefore to be in the prevention of the evolution of this epidemic. Nevertheless, I was telling you, we are arming, what is called arming resuscitation beds. We have respirators, we have protective equipment, we have resuscitation drugs to deal with a larger wave if it were necessary than the first. We have gone from some 5,000 armed resuscitation beds in our country to 5,800 sustainable beds before the crisis. But if necessary and whenever necessary, we increase resuscitation capacities. And how do we do? We are eliminating operating theaters, we are eliminating recovery rooms, we are deprogramming surgical care for patients who need it. We cannot delay care in our country and that is why we must be absolutely attentive to each other and we must support our caregivers who, as you said, Prime Minister, are tired of this first wave, who have given enormously, who will always be there if the situation should require it and I want to thank them from the bottom of my heart for that. And I know that the French associate themselves with this tribute that I pay them again today. But we must prevent rather than suffer. Finally, a word, Mr Prime Minister, on a question that arises, which was the question of so-called vulnerable people, people who suffer from chronic illnesses, sometimes mild, sometimes more severe, who had been away from work during the first vague given the risk that leaving their homes could pose to their health. A first list of people who were able to find work to avoid too long a professional disintegration had been put in place this summer. We will probably change this list in order to protect more people given the state of health emergency. A discussion has already begun with the associations responsible for users. [End of intervention by Mr Olivier VÉRAN] Thank you very much, Minister of Solidarity and Health. I would like to add that for the staff of health establishments, since we all know that the healthcare system will hold up thanks to caregivers, some important additional measures have been taken. But deep down, we know that the health system will hold thanks to caregivers. In hospitals, in EPHADs, at home, staff are faced with the challenge of caring for a growing number of people with the virus. They were the heroes of the first wave, and we're going to have to rely on them again. The caregivers are tired, they have given a lot and we understand their weariness. But I want to tell them that we still need them, and that we are doing everything we can to facilitate their living and working conditions. I signed this summer with the social partners a historic agreement to increase the value of more than €200 per month for 2 million carers, in hospitals and in EPHADs. This represents a historic investment of €8 billion for the benefit of women and men who make up our healthcare system. This SEGUR agreement resulted in a first salary increase of €90 per month in September, which for some will appear on the October payslip. A second march of €93 per month was to take place next March. In view of the situation, I am announcing that it will intervene earlier, before the end of 2020. Secondly, to face this new difficult period, we need personnel reinforcements. I announced the creation of 15,000 positions this summer, and we are doubling the training places for caregivers, nurses and carers over the next 5 years, but these recruitments necessarily take a little time. I have also decided to immediately put in place an exceptional gratuity for agents who would be required, either voluntarily or by service necessity, to increase their working hours. Thus, from October 1 to December 31, compensation for overtime worked will be increased by 50%. Third, some school leaders have indicated that they will ask their staff to be present during the All Saints holidays in order to ensure business continuity. In order to recognize in advance the commitment of agents who would thus be mobilized by service necessity, a compensatory allowance for annual leave not taken will be put in place, ranging from €110 to €200 gross per day. Thus, the most in-demand nurses will be able to receive an additional salary of up to 2,000 euros, caregivers up to 1,100 euros, i.e. the equivalent of a 13th month. Fourth, an envelope of €100 million will be delegated to regional health agencies to organize human resource management: platform management; funding for childcare and housing; funding for reinforcements. Ladies and Gentlemen, My dear fellow citizens, All of the measures we are announcing today will be clarified and adapted by Saturday. We will do this within a concerted framework: with the social partners, with the representatives of the professional sectors, with the local elected representatives with whom I am in constant contact and whom I still want to thank, with the political parties and the parliamentary groups whom I will receive again next week, in particular to discuss with them the impact of the deterioration of the health situation on the organization of the next elections. Many questions are resolved through listening and dialogue. We are going through an unprecedented moment in our history. A moment destined to last several more months. And as always in difficult times, the temptation is great to look for scapegoats, to oppose each other, to lose ourselves in futile controversies. The time will come, when this health crisis is over – and it will be! – to calmly draw all the consequences and all the lessons. But for now, all our energies must be directed towards this fight against the disease and its spread. It is within our reach, if we are united, if we are responsible. The State and the Government as a whole are of course in the front line, to protect you and take the measures that the situation requires, as do all the political authorities of neighboring countries. But it's not the state that strikes, it's the virus! He is our common goal, it is against him that we must unite our forces and our wills. France is a great country: together, we will overcome this ordeal, I am convinced of it. We are at your disposal to answer your questions.

topics_FR: 75ème anniversaire de la sécurité sociale
speeches_FR: Discours de M. Jean Castex, Premier ministre à l’occasion du 75ème anniversaire de la sécurité sociale. Jeudi 8 octobre 2020 C’est dans des circonstances très particulières que je m’exprime aujourd’hui devant vous pour célébrer ce soixante-quinzième anniversaire de la sécurité sociale. Voilà près d’un an qu’un virus inconnu a fait son apparition à l’autre bout du monde. Depuis, l’Europe et la France doivent faire face à une des pandémies les plus graves, peut-être, depuis la Grippe espagnole. Face à cette crise, nous avons pu, chaque Français a pu, constater la solidité et l’importance de notre système social. Ce système était né lui-aussi d’une crise internationale majeure, la Seconde Guerre mondiale. D’une crise à l’autre, notre système de sécurité sociale est né, a évolué, s’est réformé et a résisté. Portée par le Conseil National de la Résistance et conçue par les esprits visionnaires de Pierre Laroque, Alexandre Parodi et Ambroise Crozat, la sécurité sociale est très vite devenue la pierre angulaire de notre édifice institutionnel. Aujourd’hui, elle est le socle sur lequel est bâti le modèle social français . Ce modèle, pardonnez-moi cette expression, a montré sa puissance par rapport à d’autres formes de société et de système de protection. Les Français, quels qu’ils soient, ont été parmi les mieux protégés dans la crise sanitaire que nous traversons. Vous pouvez construire toutes les politiques de santé que vous voulez, si les malades n’ont pas les moyens de se soigner, quel que soit leur âge, leurs revenus, leur état de santé, ces mesures deviennent inefficaces parce qu’elles sont, de fait, inégalitaires. Cette maladie redoutable est venue nous rappeler que notre système était le bon. Avec ses cent-cinquante mille employés, auxquels je veux rendre hommage, la sécurité sociale a servi de rempart pour protéger les malades et leurs familles, mais aussi la société toute entière. Derrière ce rempart il y avait d’autres femmes, d’autres hommes, mobilisés jours et nuits en milieu hospitalier et dans le secteur libéral pour faire front contre l’épidémie. Honneur leur soit rendu. Aujourd’hui encore, nous devons nous tenir à leur côté. Nous avons sans délai tiré des conséquences majeures et historiques de cet événement, et ce avant même qu’il ne soit terminé. C’est l’objet du Ségur de la Santé qui est non seulement un acte de reconnaissance, mais aussi un acte de volonté, volonté d’assurer l’attractivité, le renforcement et l’efficience de notre système de santé, qui constitue plus que jamais l’un des piliers de notre sécurité sociale. Un effort de 9 milliards d’euros, qui est pour partie une remise à niveau, mais qui est inédit dans son ampleur depuis 1945. Faut-il rappeler que la sécurité sociale a démontré aussi dans cette crise d’autres forces : lors des derniers mois et dans un délai record, le revenu de tous a été garanti, les droits qui arrivaient à échéance ont été prolongés pour qu’une crise sociale ne vienne pas s’ajouter à la crise sanitaire. La sécurité sociale a non seulement protégé les malades et leurs familles, mais elle a été un véritable amortisseur économique et social qui, disons-le ici tout net, a empêché l’effondrement de la France. Bien évidemment, la sécu de 2020 n’est pas celle de 1945. Et c’est une autre force de cette institution que d’avoir su s’adapter continument aux évolutions structurelles de notre société et de notre économie : évolution de l’économie qui est passée des Trente Glorieuses à une situation de crise endémique et de croissance en berne, avec des hauts et des bas depuis 1974 ; évolution du monde du travail où l’apparition du chômage de masse s’est conjuguée avec le recul du salariat; évolution de notre structure sociale, marquée par le vieillissement de la population, les transformations de la cellule familiale et les conquêtes des femmes pour le respect de leurs droits fondamentaux, notamment dans le champ professionnel. Vous le savez, la tendance lourde de cette adaptation a conduit à l’universalisation croissante de notre Sécu, tant dans ses champs d’intervention que dans ses modes de financement. Si la sécurité sociale fut créée sur l’impulsion de l’Etat, elle ne se confondait pas avec lui et elle ne se confondra jamais avec lui. Ainsi, la couverture du risque social n’a pas été nationalisée mais bien financée par un système de cotisations obligatoirement acquittées par les employeurs et les salariés. Ce n’était pas l’Etat qui couvrait le risque mais un prélèvement sur les salaires et donc sur le travail. L’universalisation de la sécurité sociale a conduit le système à prélever ses financements audelà des seuls salaires, il a fallu faire le choix de taxer d’autres sources de richesse. Ce fut l’objet essentiel de la création par Michel Rocard de la CSG (contribution sociale généralisée). Cette évolution était évidemment indispensable à l’universalisation de la couverture sociale mais elle a eu pour corolaire l’affaiblissement du rôle des partenaires sociaux. Pourtant il ne peut y avoir de véritable esprit de responsabilité que dans le cadre d’une gouvernance faisant toute leur place aux acteurs économiques et sociaux. Le Président de la République, depuis 2017 et dans les mois qui viennent, a voulu que cette grande œuvre soit confortée et amplifiée. Dans le sens de l’égalité, de la justice et de la responsabilité, c’est-à-dire dans la fidélité aux principes fondateurs posés par le CNR. Ce quinquennat sera celui de la création de la cinquième branche dédiée à l’autonomie tant attendue et jamais réalisée jusqu’ici. Les ordonnances de 1945 cherchaient à épargner la misère aux travailleurs âgés ; soixante-quinze ans plus tard nous voulons offrir aux personnes handicapées et aux grands aînés et, sur l’ensemble du territoire national, la possibilité de choisir jusqu’au bout leur mode de vie. La loi autonomie qui sera débattue l’an prochain permettra d’en fixer les modalités. D’ores et déjà, les aidants, dont la place est appelée à devenir de plus en plus importante avec le vieillissement de notre société, peuvent depuis le 1er octobre bénéficier d’un congé indemnisé. Ainsi, ils n’ont plus à choisir entre l’attention due à leurs proches et leur place au travail. Autre réforme majeure, celle de la retraite universelle. Ce souci d’universalité qui prévalait déjà à la création même de notre système en 1945 doit maintenant trouver sa réalisation complète dans un régime universel et lisible par tous. Dès l’origine, les Pères fondateurs avaient hésité à créer un système strictement égalitaire, mais à une époque où le salariat dominait largement la société française, ils ont préféré maintenir la juxtaposition de régimes différents. Dans une société qui aspire à une plus grande égalité de droits réels, et dans laquelle le salariat n’a plus le même poids économique et social, nous devons construire ce changement. Je sais l’inquiétude que cela suscite chez certaines catégories de salariés. Comme je m’y suis engagé devant la représentation nationale, je souhaite que les partenaires sociaux prennent toute leur place dans ce projet engagé par mon prédécesseur. Nous devons également poursuivre l’engagement d’une sécurité sociale au service de l’émancipation. Il y a soixante-quinze ans, la sécurité sociale voulait protéger la vieillesse et la maternité. Aujourd’hui, la société exige l’égalité réelle. Si c’est sur la mère que reposent toutes les contraintes liées à une naissance puis la garde des enfants, jusqu’à leur scolarisation obligatoire, où est-elle, l’égalité réelle ? C’est aussi cette exigence que doit honorer la sécurité sociale, et c’est le sens que nous souhaitons donner à la politique familiale ; prévenir les accidents de la vie, et pas seulement les réparer. Depuis le 1er octobre, les femmes qui élèvent seules leurs enfants se voient garantir leur pension alimentaire grâce à la sécurité sociale. En allongeant le congé de paternité et d’accueil du jeune enfant, et en lui conférant un caractère obligatoire pour 7 jours, nous sommes au cœur de cette promesse : celle de mieux contribuer au développement de l’enfant, et celle de progresser encore vers l’égalité entre les femmes et les hommes. La sécurité sociale rend possible une véritable émancipation lorsqu’elle assume sa fonction de redistribution en donnant plus à ceux qui ont le moins. C’est ce que nous voulons avec la création de la complémentaire santé solidaire, qui offre une couverture à la fois plus simple, plus large et plus accessible à tous ceux qui ont des revenus modestes, notamment après la retraite. Toutefois, si la crise que nous traversons a révélé la force de notre système, elle est aussi venue le déstabiliser profondément. La pandémie s’est traduite par un déficit de plus de 40 milliards d’euros des comptes de la sécurité sociale. Ce sont plus de dix ans d’efforts de redressement consentis par le pays après la grave crise économique de 2008 qui ont été ainsi anéantis en quelques mois par un virus. L’investissement financier colossal que nous avons décidé – pour affronter la crise elle-même mais aussi, pour rémunérer les soignants à la hauteur du service qu’ils rendent à la France– je l’assume entièrement. Ils sont à la hauteur de l’engagement pris par le Président de la République au début de l’épidémie. Mais je partage aussi l’inquiétude de nos concitoyens qui redoutent que le poids de ce déficit ne finisse par menacer la pérennité du système. Nous avons une obligation absolue qui est d’assurer la solidité économique de notre système de protection sociale, pour que nos enfants, et leurs enfants après eux, puissent à leur tour bénéficier d’une sécurité sociale aussi protectrice qu’aujourd’hui. Les créateurs de la sécurité sociale n’envisageaient pas qu’elle puisse reposer sur une dette laissée aux générations futures. C’est d’ailleurs bien l’équilibre des comptes qui a prévalu jusqu’à la fin des années soixantedix, jusqu’au choc pétrolier et à la crise économique qui a suivi. Il ne s’agit évidemment pas d’absorber immédiatement l’impact aussi soudain qu’il a été brutal de la crise du Covid, car nous ne le pourrions pas. Nous devons cependant tracer le chemin de la responsabilité, avec les partenaires sociaux, pour un retour à l’équilibre de notre système. Nous devons être également exigeants dans la modernisation nécessaire de notre système et surtout de son efficience. C’est un combat permanent, et je sais l’engagement de toutes celles et ceux qui font vivre au quotidien la sécurité sociale. Le système construit par les Pères fondateurs et entretenu avec soin par les générations qui leur ont succédé repose avant tout sur la confiance. Pour construire cette confiance, il nous faut œuvrer pour un meilleur recours aux droits de tous les bénéficiaires et lutter fermement contre les phénomènes de fraude. Que chacun bénéficie du juste droit. Qu’aucune prestation ne soit détournée. C’est l’exigence et l’éthique qui doivent nous guider. Aujourd’hui, contrairement à ses débuts, le système de sécurité sociale n’a plus d’ennemis idéologiques et tous les Français, même les esprits les plus libéraux, se le sont appropriés. La sécurité sociale n’est pas seulement l’objet d’un consensus national, elle est consubstantielle à l’idée même que nous nous faisons du Contrat Social. Désormais, je dois le dire ici, le seul ennemi de la sécurité sociale, c’est la crise économique profonde. Le Général de Gaulle l’affirmait lui-même il y a plus de cinquante ans, l’économie reste la condition même du progrès social. Aussi, pour rétablir les comptes de la sécurité sociale, et nous les rétablirons, je ne connais que deux leviers : le travail et la restauration de la croissance. C’est la raison pour laquelle nous avons élaboré un plan de relance à 100 milliards d’euros qui s’adresse tout à la fois aux entreprises et aux particuliers mais qui a été aussi pensé et voulu pour soutenir notre système de protection sociale. Il n’existe pas à ma connaissance de politique efficace dont chaque partie ne soit solidaire les unes des autres, c’est ce que j’ai voulu vous dire aujourd’hui, dans le cadre de cette commémoration. Notre politique est globale. La sécurité sociale fait partie d’un tout, sans que cela n’enlève rien à son identité singulière et, j’ose le mot, son indépendance. Ces perspectives tracées par le Président de la République sont aussi un moyen pour nous de dépasser l’horizon de cette crise pour montrer aux Français que non seulement leur système de sécurité sociale a tenu, mais que nous allons le réformer et l’améliorer. C’est le plus sûr moyen de rester fidèles aux enseignements et à l’héritage de nos grands anciens qui avaient ouvert la voie. Je vous remercie.
topics_EN: 75th anniversary of social security
speeches_EN: Speech by Mr. Jean Castex, Prime Minister on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of social security. Thursday, October 8, 2020 It is in very special circumstances that I speak to you today to celebrate this seventy-fifth anniversary of social security. It has been almost a year since an unknown virus appeared on the other side of the world. Since then, Europe and France have had to deal with one of the most serious pandemics, perhaps, since the Spanish Flu. Faced with this crisis, we have been able, every French person has been able to see the solidity and importance of our social system. This system was also born of a major international crisis, the Second World War. From one crisis to another, our social security system was born, evolved, reformed and resisted. Driven by the National Resistance Council and designed by the visionary minds of Pierre Laroque, Alexandre Parodi and Ambroise Crozat, social security very quickly became the cornerstone of our institutional structure. Today, it is the foundation on which the French social model is built. This model, forgive me this expression, has shown its power compared to other forms of society and protection system. The French, whoever they are, have been among the best protected in the health crisis we are going through. You can build all the health policies you want, if the sick do not have the means to treat themselves, whatever their age, their income, their state of health, these measures become ineffective because they are, fact, unequal. This dreadful disease came to remind us that our system was the right one. With its 150,000 employees, to whom I would like to pay tribute, social security has served as a bulwark to protect the sick and their families, but also society as a whole. Behind this rampart there were other women, other men, mobilized day and night in hospitals and in the liberal sector to stand up against the epidemic. Honor be given to them. Even today, we must stand by their side. We immediately drew major and historic consequences from this event, even before it was over. This is the purpose of the Ségur de la Santé, which is not only an act of recognition, but also an act of will, a desire to ensure the attractiveness, strengthening and efficiency of our health system, which constitutes more than ever one of the pillars of our social security. An effort of 9 billion euros, which is partly an upgrade, but which is unprecedented in its scale since 1945. Need we recall that social security has also demonstrated other forces in this crisis: during the last months and in record time, everyone's income was guaranteed, the rights that were about to expire were extended so that a social crisis did not come on top of the health crisis. Social security not only protected the sick and their families, but it was a real economic and social shock absorber which, let us say it here bluntly, prevented the collapse of France. Of course, the social security of 2020 is not that of 1945. And it is another strength of this institution to have been able to adapt continuously to the structural evolutions of our society and our economy: evolution of the economy which went from the Glorious Thirties to a situation of endemic crisis and sluggish growth, with ups and downs since 1974; evolution of the world of work where the appearance of mass unemployment has been combined with the decline in wage employment; evolution of our social structure, marked by the aging of the population, the transformations of the family unit and the conquests of women for the respect of their fundamental rights, in particular in the professional field. As you know, the heavy trend of this adaptation has led to the growing universalization of our Secu, both in its fields of intervention and in its methods of financing. If social security was created on the impulse of the State, it was not confused with it and it will never be confused with it. Thus, social risk coverage was not nationalized but financed by a system of contributions that must be paid by employers and employees. It was not the State that covered the risk but a levy on wages and therefore on work. The universalization of social security led the system to levy its funding beyond wages alone, it was necessary to choose to tax other sources of wealth. This was the essential object of the creation by Michel Rocard of the CSG (generalized social contribution). This development was obviously essential for the universalization of social security coverage, but it had the corollary of the weakening of the role of the social partners. However, there can only be a true spirit of responsibility within the framework of governance that gives full consideration to economic and social actors. The President of the Republic, since 2017 and in the months to come, wanted this great work to be reinforced and amplified. In the sense of equality, justice and responsibility, that is to say in fidelity to the founding principles laid down by the CNR. This quinquennium will be that of the creation of the fifth branch dedicated to the long-awaited and never achieved autonomy. The 1945 ordinances sought to spare older workers misery; seventy-five years later, we want to offer people with disabilities and older adults, throughout the country, the possibility of choosing their way of life to the end. The autonomy law that will be debated next year will make it possible to set the terms. Already, caregivers, whose role is set to become increasingly important as our society ages, can benefit from paid leave since October 1st. Thus, they no longer have to choose between the attention due to their loved ones and their place at work. Another major reform is that of universal retirement. This concern for universality which already prevailed at the very creation of our system in 1945 must now find its full realization in a universal system that can be read by all. From the outset, the Founding Fathers had hesitated to create a strictly egalitarian system, but at a time when wage labor largely dominated French society, they preferred to maintain the juxtaposition of different regimes. In a society that aspires to greater equality of real rights, and in which the workforce no longer has the same economic and social weight, we must build this change. I know the concern that this arouses among certain categories of employees. As I made a commitment to the national representation, I would like the social partners to play their full role in this project initiated by my predecessor. We must also pursue the commitment of social security in the service of emancipation. Seventy-five years ago, social security wanted to protect old age and maternity. Today, society demands real equality. If it is on the mother that rests all the constraints related to a birth then the custody of the children, until their compulsory schooling, where is it, real equality? It is also this requirement that social security must honour, and it is the meaning that we wish to give to family policy; prevent the accidents of life, and not just repair them. Since October 1, women who raise their children alone have been guaranteed their alimony through social security. By extending paternity leave and taking care of young children, and making it compulsory for 7 days, we are at the heart of this promise: that of better contributing to the development of the child, and that of making further progress towards equality between women and men. Social security makes true emancipation possible when it fulfills its redistributive function by giving more to those who have less. This is what we want with the creation of complementary health insurance, which offers coverage that is simpler, broader and more accessible to all those with modest incomes, especially after retirement. However, if the crisis we are going through has revealed the strength of our system, it has also come to destabilize it deeply. The pandemic has resulted in a deficit of more than 40 billion euros in social security accounts. More than ten years of recovery efforts made by the country after the serious economic crisis of 2008 were thus wiped out in a few months by a virus. The colossal financial investment that we have decided - to face the crisis itself but also, to remunerate the caregivers at the height of the service they render to France - I fully assume it. They live up to the commitment made by the President of the Republic at the start of the epidemic. But I also share the concern of our fellow citizens who fear that the weight of this deficit will end up threatening the sustainability of the system. We have an absolute obligation, which is to ensure the economic solidity of our social protection system, so that our children, and their children after them, can in turn benefit from social security that is as protective as it is today. The creators of social security did not envisage that it could be based on a debt left to future generations. It was indeed the balance of accounts that prevailed until the end of the 1970s, until the oil shock and the economic crisis that followed. It is obviously not a question of immediately absorbing the impact as sudden as it was brutal of the Covid crisis, because we could not. We must however trace the path of responsibility, with the social partners, for a return to the balance of our system. We must also be demanding in the necessary modernization of our system and especially its efficiency. It's a permanent fight, and I know the commitment of all those who bring social security to life on a daily basis. The system built by the Founding Fathers and carefully maintained by the generations that followed them is above all based on trust. To build this trust, we must work for better use of the rights of all beneficiaries and fight firmly against the phenomena of fraud. That everyone enjoys the just right. That no benefit is diverted. It is the requirement and the ethics that must guide us. Today, contrary to its beginnings, the social security system no longer has any ideological enemies and all French people, even the most liberal minds, have made it their own. Social security is not only the object of a national consensus, it is consubstantial with the very idea that we have of the Social Contract. From now on, I must say it here, the only enemy of social security is the deep economic crisis. General de Gaulle affirmed it himself more than fifty years ago, the economy remains the very condition of social progress. Also, to restore the social security accounts, and we will restore them, I only know of two levers: work and the restoration of growth. This is the reason why we have drawn up a 100 billion euro recovery plan which is aimed at both companies and individuals but which has also been designed and intended to support our social protection system. To my knowledge, there is no effective policy in which each party is not in solidarity with each other, that is what I wanted to tell you today, as part of this commemoration. Our policy is global. Social security is part of a whole, without that taking anything away from its singular identity and, I dare say, its independence. These perspectives outlined by the President of the Republic are also a way for us to go beyond the horizon of this crisis to show the French people that not only has their social security system held up, but that we are going to reform and improve it. This is the surest way to stay true to the teachings and heritage of our great elders who paved the way. Thank you.

topics_FR: Déclaration de M. Jean Castex, Premier ministre
speeches_FR: Un Conseil de Défense consacré à la crise sanitaire s’est tenu ce jour autour du Président de la République. Comme nous le faisons à intervalle régulier, nous avons analysé l’évolution de la situation épidémiologique. Celle-ci fait apparaître une dégradation manifeste de la situation : le virus circule de plus en plus en France. Le taux d’incidence est monté à 72 cas pour 100 000 personnes, contre 57 il y a une semaine. Le pourcentage des cas positifs augmente. Un élément suscite particulièrement notre inquiétude : pour la première fois depuis de longues semaines, nous constatons une augmentation sensible du nombre de personnes hospitalisées. Or les personnes qui arrivent en réanimation sont les mêmes qu’au mois de mars. Tout confirme que le virus n’a pas baissé en intensité, avec une proportion toujours aussi élevée de personnes âgées. Cela signifie qu’il n’y a pas de ligne Maginot : même si le virus circule principalement chez les jeunes, dont beaucoup ne présentent aucun symptôme, il finit inévitablement par toucher les plus vulnérables, pour lesquelles le virus présente un danger. Face à cette épidémie, notre stratégie ne varie pas : lutter contre le virus en évitant de devoir mettre entre parenthèse notre vie sociale, culturelle, économique, l’éducation de nos enfants et notre capacité à vivre normalement. Oui, le virus est là pour quelques mois encore, et nous devons réussir à vivre avec lui sans nous laisser entrainer à nouveau dans une logique de confinement généralisé. La solution la plus simple et la moins contraignante, on la connaît : c’est appliquer scrupuleusement les gestes-barrière. Cela dépend fondamentalement de nous. Je l’ai déjà dit, la période estivale a été marquée par une forme de relâchement que l’on peut probablement expliquer après les longues semaines de confinement du printemps dernier. La rentrée est là. Nous devons impérativement respecter les règles de distanciation physique, nous laver régulièrement les mains, porter le masque, ce que l’immense majorité de nos concitoyens fait, en application des dispositions que nous avons prises, et je les en remercie. L’autre pilier de notre stratégie, c’est dépister massivement et casser ainsi les chaines de contamination. Nous réalisons aujourd’hui plus d’1 million de tests par semaine. C’est considérable. La France est ainsi devenu le 3ème pays qui teste le plus en Europe. Cette très forte augmentation du nombre de tests est une excellente nouvelle. Elle a cependant entraîné des temps d’attente trop importants, nous avons parfaitement conscience, notamment dans certaines villes. Attendre, ce n’est pas grave s’il n’y a pas d’urgence. Mais cela est problématique lorsque vous êtes prioritaire. Quand êtes-vous prioritaire ? Vous êtes prioritaire si vous présentez les symptômes de la COVID-19, si vous avez été en contact rapproché avec une personne positive et enfin si vous êtes un personnel soignant ou assimilé travaillant à l’hôpital, dans un EPHAD ou à domicile. Pour ces personnes prioritaires, nous allons renforcer les circuits dédiés de dépistage. Ainsi, les laboratoires leur réserveront certains créneaux horaires et nous veillerons là où il y a des besoins, et notamment dans les grandes villes, à installer des tentes de dépistages qui leur seront également dédiées. Pour les personnes testées positives et celles avec lesquelles elles ont été en contact, le Conseil de Défense a pris deux décisions pour améliorer la surveillance épidémiologique : première décision, 2000 recrutements supplémentaires seront effectués au sein de l’Assurance Maladie et dans les Agences Régionales de Santé pour réaliser ce qu’on appelle le traçage ;deuxième décision, sur proposition du conseil scientifique, la durée d’isolement sera ramenée à 7 jours, c’est-à-dire la durée pendant laquelle il y a un véritable risque de contagion. Il est primordial que chacun respecte strictement cette durée d’isolement qui donnera lieu à des contrôles. Par ailleurs, le Conseil de Défense a porté à 42 le nombre de départements classés rouge, c’est-à-dire à circulation active du virus. Ce classement n’emporte pas de conséquences automatiques mais il permet aux préfets, en lien avec les autorités sanitaires et les élus locaux, de déclencher des mesures supplémentaires de réduction des risques, notamment sur le port du masque, les rassemblements sur l’espace public, les grands événements ou les horaires d’ouvertures de certains commerces. Comme je l’ai toujours dit, ces mesures ne doivent pas se décider depuis Paris, dans l’idée de s’appliquer partout, au même moment et de la même manière. Nous conserverons cette méthode qui devra nous permettre d’agir sans attendre que les choses se dégradent. Dans deux métropoles – Marseille et Bordeaux – ainsi qu’en Guadeloupe, nous constatons une évolution préoccupante des contaminations, notamment chez les plus âgés, ainsi qu’un taux déjà élevé d’hospitalisation. Compte tenu des prévisions que nous pouvons faire à 3 semaines sur l’occupation des lits de réanimation, j’ai demandé aux préfets concernés de me proposer d’ici lundi, et après avoir mené les concertations locales nécessaires, un ensemble de nouvelles mesures complémentaires. Nous continuerons à prendre les mesures adaptées et graduées en fonction de l’évolution de la situation sanitaire et de son anticipation. Ainsi que je l’ai annoncé, le ministre des Solidarités et de la Santé reprendra ses points d’information réguliers. J’en appelle aujourd’hui solennellement au sens des responsabilités de chacune et chacun d’entre vous. Nous ne parviendrons à enrayer cette reprise de l’épidémie qu’en étant tous vigilants et solidaires. Je demande en particulier aux personnes âgées d’observer la plus grande prudence au quotidien. Faites attention, soyez très prudents. Pour quelques mois encore, nous devons faire preuve d’une responsabilité de tous les instants, d’un civisme exigent. Demain dépend de vous, de nous. Je vous remercie.
topics_EN: Statement by Mr. Jean Castex, Prime Minister
speeches_EN: A Defense Council devoted to the health crisis was held today around the President of the Republic. As we do at regular intervals, we have analyzed the evolution of the epidemiological situation. This shows a clear deterioration in the situation: the virus is circulating more and more in France. The incidence rate has risen to 72 cases per 100,000 people, from 57 a week ago. The percentage of positive cases is increasing. One element is of particular concern to us: for the first time in many weeks, we are seeing a significant increase in the number of people hospitalized. However, the people arriving in intensive care are the same as in March. Everything confirms that the virus has not decreased in intensity, with a still high proportion of elderly people. This means that there is no Maginot line: even if the virus circulates mainly among young people, many of whom show no symptoms, it inevitably ends up affecting the most vulnerable, for whom the virus poses a danger. Faced with this epidemic, our strategy does not vary: fight against the virus by avoiding having to put on hold our social, cultural, economic life, the education of our children and our ability to live normally. Yes, the virus is here for a few more months, and we must manage to live with it without letting ourselves be dragged back into a logic of generalized confinement. The simplest and least restrictive solution, we know it: it is to scrupulously apply barrier gestures. It basically depends on us. As I have already said, the summer period was marked by a form of relaxation that can probably be explained after the long weeks of confinement last spring. The comeback is here. We must imperatively respect the rules of physical distancing, wash our hands regularly, wear the mask, which the vast majority of our fellow citizens do, in application of the measures we have taken, and I thank them for that. The other pillar of our strategy is to screen massively and thus break the chains of contamination. We now perform more than 1 million tests per week. It is considerable. France has thus become the 3rd country that tests the most in Europe. This very strong increase in the number of tests is excellent news. However, it has led to excessive waiting times, as we are well aware, especially in certain cities. Waiting is okay if there is no urgency. But this is problematic when you have priority. When do you have priority? You have priority if you have the symptoms of COVID-19, if you have been in close contact with a positive person and finally if you are a nursing or similar staff working in the hospital, in an EPHAD or at home. For these priority people, we are going to strengthen the dedicated screening circuits. Thus, the laboratories will reserve certain time slots for them and we will make sure, where there is a need, and in particular in the big cities, to set up screening tents which will also be dedicated to them. For people who tested positive and those with whom they were in contact, the Defense Council took two decisions to improve epidemiological surveillance: first decision, 2,000 additional recruitments will be made within the Health Insurance and in the Regional Health Agencies Health to carry out what is called tracing; second decision, on the proposal of the scientific council, the duration of isolation will be reduced to 7 days, that is to say the duration during which there is a real risk of contagion . It is essential that everyone strictly respects this period of isolation which will give rise to checks. In addition, the Defense Council has increased to 42 the number of departments classified red, that is to say with active circulation of the virus. This classification does not have automatic consequences but it allows prefects, in conjunction with health authorities and local elected officials, to trigger additional risk reduction measures, in particular on the wearing of masks, gatherings in public spaces. , major events or the opening hours of certain businesses. As I have always said, these measures should not be decided from Paris, with the idea of applying everywhere, at the same time and in the same way. We will keep this method which should allow us to act without waiting for things to deteriorate. In two metropolises – Marseille and Bordeaux – as well as in Guadeloupe, we are seeing a worrying evolution of contamination, especially among the oldest, as well as an already high rate of hospitalization. Given the forecasts that we can make at 3 weeks on the occupation of intensive care beds, I have asked the prefects concerned to propose to me by Monday, and after having carried out the necessary local consultations, a set of new additional measures . We will continue to take appropriate and graduated measures according to the evolution of the health situation and its anticipation. As I announced, the Minister of Solidarity and Health will resume his regular briefings. Today I solemnly appeal to the sense of responsibility of each and every one of you. We will only be able to stop this resumption of the epidemic by being vigilant and united. I ask the elderly in particular to observe the greatest caution in everyday life. Be careful, be very careful. For a few more months, we must demonstrate constant responsibility and demanding civic-mindedness. Tomorrow depends on you, on us. Thank you.

topics_FR: Discours de M. Jean Castex, Premier ministre - conférence de presse sur la Covid-19
speeches_FR: Messieurs les ministres, Mesdames et messieurs, bonjour à toutes et à tous.
